channel.title: NYT > World
channel.copyright: Copyright 2014 The New York Times Company

item.title: Grief and Anger in Afghanistan Over Killing of 21 Soldiers
item.description: As some Afghans began raising money for the soldiers’ families, many expressed outrage at the fact that they had been killed in their sleep.
item.dc:creator: By ROD NORDLAND and HARIS KAKAR

item.title: Kremlin Says Ukrainian Instability Threatens Russian Interests
item.description: Russia’s prime minister, Dmitri A. Medvedev, questioned the legitimacy of the new government in Ukraine, signaling that the Kremlin could react strongly in response to the tumult there.
item.dc:creator: By STEVEN LEE MYERS

item.title: Suicide Bombing Strikes Near Iranian Consulate in Pakistan
item.description: Two were killed and 11 were wounded nearby, but none were hurt in the consulate complex because of security that diverted the attacker.
item.dc:creator: By ISMAIL KHAN

item.title: Egypt’s Prime Minister and Cabinet Abruptly Resign
item.description: The departure of Hazem el-Beblawi and his cabinet after seven difficult months may clear the way for Abdul-Fattah el-Sisi to run for president.
item.category: Middle East and North Africa Unrest (2010- )
item.dc:creator: By KAREEM FAHIM and MAYY EL SHEIKH
item.media:description: Prime Minister Hazem el-Beblawi leaving government headquarters on Monday.

item.title: Sinosphere Blog: China Accused of Firing Water Cannons at Filipino Fishermen
item.description: The Philippine military said the Chinese Coast Guard tried to drive away Filipino fishing vessels at the disputed Scarborough Shoal.
item.dc:creator: By BREE FENG
item.media:description: Gen. Emmanuel Bautista, left, chief of staff of the Philippine Armed Forces, with U.S. Ambassador Philip Goldberg on Monday at a forum of the Foreign Correspondents Association of the Philippines.

item.title: Acting Officials in Ukraine Seek Stability and Ousted Leader
item.description: The acting interior minister accused former President Viktor F. Yanukovych of mass killing of protesters, and said he had fled to an unknown location.
item.dc:creator: By DAVID M. HERSZENHORN
item.media:credit: Sergey Ponomarev for The New York Times
item.media:description: People in Kiev's Independence Square on Monday mourned those killed in recent demonstrations.

item.title: India Ink: Leopard on Loose Paralyzes Northern Indian City
item.description: The big cat has attacked a police official, a TV news cameraman and four residents.
item.dc:creator: By HARI KUMAR
item.media:description: A leopard leaping across a building under construction in Meerut, Uttar Pradesh.

item.title: How a Kingpin Above the Law Fell, Incredibly, Without a Shot
item.description: The takedown of the world’s most wanted man — Joaquín Guzmán Loera, the head of a sophisticated narcotics enterprise — upended assumptions about the impunity of Mexican mobsters.
item.dc:creator: By DAMIEN CAVE
item.media:credit: Kirsten Luce for The New York Times
item.media:description: The hotel-condominium where Joaquín Guzmán Loera was arrested, the Miramar, attracted bystanders on Sunday, many of whom took photos.

item.title: Ugandan President Signs Antigay Law
item.description: The move by President Yoweri Museveni came after similar measures in Nigeria prompted violence against homosexuals.
item.category: Human Rights and Human Rights Violations
item.dc:creator: By ALAN COWELL

item.title: Despite Stroke, Algerian Leader Says He’ll Run for Re-Election
item.description: The announcement that Abdelaziz Bouteflika will run again ended months of speculation about the country’s leadership.
item.category: Middle East and North Africa Unrest (2010- )
item.dc:creator: By CARLOTTA GALL

item.title: Adelson Says He Would Spend Billions to Win Japan Casino
item.description: The chief of Las Vegas Sands is considered a strong candidate to win a license if Japan, one of the largest untapped gambling markets, approves a law.
item.dc:creator: By REUTERS

item.title: Honda Appoints First Woman to Board
item.description: In another significant move, the automaker also gave a major promotion to a foreigner, signaling an effort to change perceptions.
item.dc:creator: By THE ASSOCIATED PRESS

item.title: Sinosphere Blog: Young, Rich, and Too Fast for L.A.
item.description: Commentators and social media in China have erupted in sarcasm and anger after a Chinese college student was booked for a high-speed car chase in the United States. He faces criminal charges.
item.dc:creator: By DIDI KIRSTEN TATLOW

item.title: Sinosphere Blog: Military Brick-Breaking Demonstrations Face the Chop
item.description: Military officials are acknowledging that displays of showmanship by troops have few practical applications, and are reconsidering the amount of time that troops spend on such training.
item.dc:creator: By AUSTIN RAMZY
item.media:description: A Chinese soldier smashes bricks on a colleague's head during joint Chinese-Indian anti-terrorism exercises in Kunming in 2007.

item.title: The Lede: Turks Protest New Internet Restrictions, in the Streets and Online
item.description: Turks took to the streets, and social networks, to protest new legislation that increases the government’s power to remove content from the web that might embarrass officials.
item.dc:creator: By SEBNEM ARSU

item.title: Sinosphere Blog: Old Railroad Stirs Memories of a Pre-Industrial China
item.description: A reporter visits his family’s ancestral home in Guangdong Province, where his father had taken the old Xinning Railway in 1936 with his family, Hong Kongers who were going into the lush countryside to build a new family home.
item.dc:creator: By EDWARD WONG

item.title: India Ink: Underneath the Quiet in Kashmir, Youthful Anger Simmers
item.description: Behind closed doors, young Kashmiris are increasingly talking of violence, frustrated with their inability to protest in the streets and losing faith in separatist leaders.
item.dc:creator: By BETWA SHARMA
item.media:description: Policemen patrolling a road in Srinagar, Jammu and Kashmir, during a strike called by political groups to press their demand of the return of the remains of separatist leader Muhammad Afzal on Feb. 11. Mr. Afzal was hanged last year for his role in the attack on the Indian Parliament in 2001.

item.title: News Analysis: Deeply Bound to Ukraine, Putin Watches and Waits for Next Move
item.description: Mr. Putin faces the task of reasserting Russia’s influence in a country that it considers an ally with deep cultural, social and political connections, since the Kremlin-backed government has collapsed.
item.dc:creator: By STEVEN LEE MYERS
item.media:description: President Vladimir V. Putin during the closing ceremony of the Sochi Olympic Games.

item.title: Jihadist Mediator Killed in Suicide Attack by Rival Extremists
item.description: Opposition activists blamed the extremist group Islamic State in Iraq and Syria for the bombing in which five others were also killed.
item.category: Middle East and North Africa Unrest (2010- )
item.dc:creator: By BEN HUBBARD

item.title: Venezuela Is Divided Even on Its Death Toll
item.description: At least 11 people have died in the antigovernment demonstrations, though officials disagreed over whether the latest death was related to the protests.
item.dc:creator: By WILLIAM NEUMAN
item.media:description: In the capital, Caracas, the government organized a rally.

item.title: Milan Journal: Moving Leonardo’s Horse: A Question of Logistics or Pedigree?
item.description: A statue that was meant to pay homage to a destroyed 15th-century work by Leonardo da Vinci has been relegated to a racetrack in Milan, far from the public eye. Now some are trying to find a more suitable home.
item.dc:creator: By ELISABETTA POVOLEDO
item.media:credit: Alessandro Grassani for The New York Times
item.media:description: Since arriving in 1999, a statue based on one by Leonardo da Vinci has been on display at a racetrack. Some in Milan would like to see it in a more prominent location for the 2015 World Expo.

item.title: Power Shift Inspires Joy in Kiev, Fury in East
item.description: Two gatherings in the coal-mining city of Donetsk illustrated the diverse forces tugging at Ukraine now that President Viktor F. Yanukovych has fled the capital.
item.dc:creator: By ALISON SMALE
item.media:credit: Uriel Sinai for The New York Times
item.media:description: Supporters of President Viktor F. Yanukovych rallied in Donetsk, Ukraine, on Sunday. Pro-democracy activists also gathered in Donetsk, where Mr. Yanukovych built his political career.

item.title: Fresh From Prison, a Former Prime Minister Returns to the Political Stage
item.description: Yulia V. Tymoshenko denied seeking a new political role amid speculation that she might want to resume her duties as prime minister.
item.dc:creator: By DAVID M. HERSZENHORN
item.media:description: From left, the American ambassador Geoffrey R. Pyatt, Yulia V. Tymoshenko, and Jan Tombinski of the European Union.

item.title: Sochi Olympics Construction Weighs on City’s Future
item.description: After a building boom, Sochi needs tourists but has no clear strategy for attracting them now that the Olympics are over.
item.dc:creator: By DAVID SEGAL
item.media:description: Rosa Khutor, which hosted downhill events, plans to continue operating as a ski resort.

item.title: In Manhattan, Children of Ukrainians Connect to Revolution
item.description: Streaming video and social media fostered a sense of involvement in the recent political upheaval.
item.dc:creator: By ANNIE CORREAL
item.media:description: Photos of protesters killed in the recent Ukrainian revolution were printed out by children for a memorial in the East Village.
